indicators.justification:
The climate vulnerability information and data of Nepal are scattered among the various government agencies and civil societies. Being the Himalayan county, Nepal is in the high-risk zone due to climate change and there have been multiple numbers of research carried out to study the water resources [1], glaciers lakes [2], river basins [3], etc. Nepal Climate Change and Development portal [4] contains many such research resources related to climate change and vulnerabilities. Some of the major sources which contain the climate vulnerability information are the Department of Hydrology and Meteorology [5], which provided flood forecasting under the Flood Forecasting Division [6] and provides real-time data on rainfall and river watch. There is also a BIPAD portal [7], which informs the users about the details of an incident for both natural and non-natural hazards for response and for historical analysis of loss and damage, and Nepal Disaster Risk Reduction Portal [8], which provide a summary on incidents like animal incidents, landslide, snakebite, and floods. Some of the mentioned portals do provide the data in an interactive format and mostly real-time. The required data can be also requested from the respective government agencies.

[1] Water Resources of Nepal in the context of Climate Change: http://www.wecs.gov.np/storage/listies/October2020/water-recource-climate-change.pdf
[2] Impact of Climate Change on Himalayan Glaciers and Glacier Lakes: Case Studies on GLOF and Associated Hazards in Nepal and Bhutan: https://climatenepal.org.np/resources/impact-climate-change-himalayan-glaciers-and-glacier-lakes-case-studies-glof-and
[3] Assessment of Flood and Inundation in Lower West Rapti River Basin under the effects of Climate Change: https://ndri.org.np/wp-content/uploads/2017/11/2012_Jan_Assessment-of-Flood-and-Inundation-in-Lower-West-Rapti-River-Basin-under-the-effects-of-Climate-Change.pdf

[6] Flood Forecasting Division: https://www.hydrology.gov.np
[7] BIPAD portal: https://bipadportal.gov.np/
[8] Nepal Disaster Risk Reduction Portal: http://drrportal.gov.np/

indicators.justification:
The Office of the Company Registrar has made the company information data available online as part of their Open Government Data (OGD) initiatives [1], but the data seems to lack a vast amount of other required information like the details of the accounts, directors, shareholders, license, etc [2]. It hasn't been updated in a timely manner, as the data is available for 75 districts only, whereas, after the adoption of the new constitution in 2015 [3], the country has been restructured in 77 districts [4] following the new administrative division. Also, the issues of permanence have been identified, the datasets are available only via the URL of the old website [5]. The new website of the  Office of the Company Registrar only has the basic statistics [6] and no space for data access and downloads.

indicators.justification:
The federal Department of National ID and Civil Registration is the main entity responsible for the day-to-day management of the national VR system. It is housed in the Ministry of Home Affairs and maintains the system's central server, disseminates the data, and provides technical support and capacity building to local entities [1] (page 24/25/26). The basic statistics of the vital registration can be accessed from the Search Dashboard [2] available at the Department of National ID and Civil Registration website [3], but in-depth civil registration and vital statistics (CRVS) information are not available online. Some data are also available at the published Civil Registration Report 2070-2071 [4] and Vital Events Report 2072 [5]. Since the government has the Vital  Events  Registration and Social Protection Management Information System (VERSP-MIS), we can assume that we can request the data by visiting the respective government agencies. Also, the basic data which are available online are locked in PDF.

[1] Nepal's data landscape - Civil registration and vital statistics (page 24/25/26): http://www.d4dnepal.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/2020.pdf
[2] Vital Registration Search Dashboard: https://donidcr.gov.np/SSData/VitalStat

indicators.justification:
The COVID data portal of the Ministry of Health and Population has the data about the real-time capacity of the healthcare system available in different places of Nepal [1]. However, the data captured is not updated frequently, and some data points were inaccurate, making them virtually unusable [2]. The Health Emergency Operation Center [3] and the Annual Report 2017/18 [4] of the Department of Health Services tentatively have the details of the available health services of Nepal. But the portal lacks other information related to the availability of medical devices, supplies, tests, and vaccine information. The data is also not available in the machine-readable format and in the national language and was last updated one month ago.

indicators.justification:
The data of the total number of people vaccinated with the first dose and fully is included in the daily situation reports [1] published by the Ministry of Health and Population, Nepal. The data also has the details of the province-wise statistics of dose administration with the type of vaccine (page 4 of situation reports) [2] but lack the district and local level statistics. Due to the lack of a proper mechanism to track the vaccine data and information, Nepal has seen the misuse of vaccines by the local leader and people with powers [3]. Also, the available data is in PDF format making its reuse difficult and the use of the license is not explicitly mentioned. The breakdown of data as per gender, age, disability status, etc is also not available. The volunteer groups are advocating to make vaccine information accessible & distribution transparent & equitable [4].

[1] COVID Situation Reports Of Nepal: https://covid19.mohp.gov.np/situation-report
[2] Situation Reports no #543: https://covid19.mohp.gov.np/covid/englishSituationReport/610bc1d54574b_SitRep543_COVID-19_05-08-2021_EN.pdf 
[3] Local leaders misuse senior citizens' share of vaccines in different districts: https://english.onlinekhabar.com/covid-19-nepal-local-leaders-misuse-senior-citizens-share-of-vaccines-in-different-districts.html
[4] Track My Vaccine: https://twitter.com/TrackMyVac

indicators.justification:
The data of existing land use information of Nepal is not available as open data, it is probably because the country has recently embarked on the journey of digitizing land data and revenue [1]. Also, an integrated system for the land data is missing therefore the data are scattered between various government departments as PDF reports. Like, Survey Department Nepal [2] holds some data related to boundaries, whereas the Department of Forest And Soil Conservation [3] holds the land data covered by forest and agriculture, the Department of Land Reforms and Management [4] holds the land data owned by the public and individuals, etc. The data are not available online and are not in a machine-readable format. A minimum charge has to be paid to access the vector data as defined in the digital data distribution, use, and monitoring guideline 2065 [5]. The civil societies and international organizations have also played some role in studying the land cover information of Nepal [6].

[2] Survey Department Nepal: http://www.dos.gov.np/downloads/acts

[4] Department of Land Management and Archive: http://dolrm.gov.np/home
[5] Digital data distribution, use, and monitoring guideline 2065: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1vQh0wOroU9TQm8XfLcrRH_hTN889fl79/view?usp=sharing

indicators.justification:
Nepal currently doesn't have any kind of online portal or system from where detailed land tenure information can be accessed as open data [1]. Most of the land administration-related services are manual and paper-based [2]. For the past 5 years, Nepal has started using Land Records Information Management System (LRIMS) but it has been implemented only at 108 land reform and revenue offices [3] [4]. Some of the registered users can access and print the map of the land which they own via the Public Access Portal of Survey Department Nepal [5] but the full land tenure information can't be accessed.

indicators.justification:
The Ministry of Finance, each individual ministry, and government institutions are responsible for preparing the yearly budget in Nepal. The Ministry of Finance prepares and publishes the Budget Details Red Book [1] which consists of the national level budget details, whereas the Financial Comptroller General Office (FCGO) [2] tracks the spending data. The consolidated financial statements [3] consist of the details of the spending data and we can also use the daily budgetary analysis tool [4] to explore the daily revenue and expenditure details of the national government. The Office of Auditor General [5] audits the government spending data each year. The audit reports of the spending by local levels [6], provincial levels [7], state-owned enterprises [8], and others are available at the office of the auditor general website. In parliament, the Public Accounts Committee oversees spending irregularities. Most of the datasets are available in a non-machine-readable format and are not open licensed.

[1] Budget Details Red Book: https://www.mof.gov.np/site/publication-category/28

[6] Spending audits at local levels: https://oag.gov.np/local-level/report/en
[7] Spending audits at provincial levels: https://oag.gov.np/menu-category/962/en
[8] Spending audits of state-owned enterprises: https://oag.gov.np/menu-category/934/en

indicators.justification:
Under section - 31a. "Provision relating to property details" (page 23) of the Commission for the Investigation of Abuse of Authority Act 1991 [1] the point (3) of the section says that the property statement so submitted under this Section shall be kept confidential. Given this, the statement may be given to the concerned authority on-demand in course of initiating investigation and inquiry under this Act. Therefore, the asset declarations submitted by members of the government and civil servants are confidential and cannot be accessed by the wider public [2] and are not available online.

indicators.justification:
According to the Political Parties Act, 2058 (2002), the registered political parties are required to publicize their annual financial report [1]. The political party is responsible for publishing it. The official responsible for disclosure is the party treasurer. But the parties' statutes are silent on the issue of disclosing their financial records to the broader public. According to the Transparency International Nepal [2] reports on the Transparency in Political Finance in Nepal [3], "Dimension 6: Disclosure of information to the public (page 21)" says that parties do not have incentives to declare donations, since the idea of contributing to political parties and individual candidates is not regarded positively, as they are viewed as a way of buying favors. On the other hand, there is no public pressure on parties to publish information on internal finance and become more transparent. Neither the state nor civil society has been successful in influencing the parties on internal governance rules which, still seem to be very much based on an autocratic hierarchy with little urge to move towards transparency and public participation. Therefore the political finance information is not available. Election Commission Nepal [4], who is responsible for collecting that information hasn't published the data.

[1] Political Parties Act, 2058 (2002): https://www.lawcommission.gov.np/en/archives/category/documents/law-archives/statutes-acts-law-archives/political-parties-act-2058-2002

[3] Report on Transparency in Political Finance in Nepal: http://www.tinepal.org/tmp-content/uploads/2015/02/Transparency-in-Political-Finance.pdf
[4] Election Commission Nepal: https://www.election.gov.np/election/en

indicators.justification:
Despite the constitutional guarantee, it took almost two decades for specific RTI legislation to be adopted in Nepal [1]. As defined in the Preamble, the aim of the act is to make the functions of the state open, transparent, responsible, and accountable to citizens in accordance with the democratic system. The in-detail data and information of the RIT performance are not available as open data, but the National Information Commission [2], which is one of the main government entities responsible for implementing RIT in Nepal publish the cumulative details of the RIT request made via them and its progress in their annual reports [3]. The NIC reports annually on its activities to the parliament through the prime minister and makes available the annual report for the public. The data is not available in the machine-readable format as the reports are available in the PDF format. The interactive open dashboard is also not available, although the NIC has the PDMS System [4], which is accessible to government agencies.

[1] Country Report: The Right to Information in Nepal: https://www.article19.org/resources/country-report-the-right-to-information-in-nepal/

[3] NIC Annual Report: https://nic.gov.np/category/annual-reports
[4] PDMS System: https://nic.gov.np/auth/admin-login

indicators.justification:
The Public Procurement Monitoring Office [1] of Nepal has made significant progress in terms of opening the public procurement data of Nepal using the e-Government Procurement (e-GP) System [2] and Public Procurement Transparency Initiative [3]. The details of the recently published bids and e-contracts can be accessed via the e-Government Procurement System using the search function of the system. Whereas the data can be visually explored and download using the Public Procurement Transparency Initiative. The data made available via the e-Government Procurement System is real-time and updated on the daily basis, where the data of the Public Procurement Transparency Initiative is made available on the yearly basis. The Open Contracting Partnership has played a vital role in making the data accessible by supporting the Government of Nepal and civil societies [4] [5]. The licensing of the datasets looks unclear as it's not explicitly mentioned and the gaps seen in the tracking of the contract implementation stage need to be improved. The sub-national governments [6] are also incubating the infrastructure management system to track the project and its distributions across procurement types.

indicators.justification:
Nepal currently doesn't have any evidence of the government providing support for data reuse. There is the need to strengthen the capacities of all spheres of government to make data-informed decisions and established norms of data sharing are missing in all spheres of government [1]. Also, the need to strengthen policy and governance frameworks to challenge the regulatory uncertainty that is preventing data sharing and re-use is also there [2]. Despite the demand [3], there remains a lack of trusted and relevant data available in usable formats to meet these needs as the legislative restrictions to data sharing have grown. The journey of the Nepal government in providing support for data reuse looks far behind.

indicators.justification:
Nepal still lacks the government-led open government data initiative. Due to limited official mechanisms for public sharing of government data, the data is often published in a manner that prevents re-use, for example in hard copy as tables or analysis in reports or embedded in websites as web text or in downloadable PDFs. (chapter - Nepal's evolving context for data, page 9) [1]. The Central Bureau of Statistics has launched the National Data Profile system [2] that provides data and information related to geography, natural resources, environment, demographics, social, economic, and governance, etc but the portal doesn't follow the open data principles and is not timely updated. Also, over years the legislative restrictions to data sharing have grown, and since the Open Government Data Action Plan which was submitted to the Prime Minister's Office still awaits approval [3], due to which there is no allocated budget for the open data team and activities with the government. In the meantime, a few civil society initiatives like Open Data Nepal [4], Open Nepal [5], Nepal in Data [6], etc have been filling the data gaps.

indicators.justification:
Decentralization remains a key challenge for Nepal. A 2015 research by Open Knowledge Nepal to study open data at local levels found that "the enthusiasm and progress shown by the central government in terms of open data projects have yet to catch on at the local level" [1]. Nepal's data landscape report [2] by the Data for Development Nepal has also shown that the limited data management capacity of federal, provincial, district, and local governments. Although some of the local governments are found developing the data portal and system [3] under the project, it still needs to be adopted by all spheres of the government. Currently, all spheres of government have to follow the same standard website format [4], which is not data-friendly.

indicators.justification:
The Nepal Administrative Staff College [1], which is the national level autonomous institution responsible for providing necessary training on career development for the employees of the Government of Nepal and Public Enterprises doesn't have any dedicated curriculum and training program to develop civil servants' data literacy and data skills. But there is isolated evidence of the government supporting civil servants' training on data matters, usually by attending and supporting the training program organized by civil society. The various departments of the government agencies have been supporting events [2] and have collaborated to organize national level substantive training [3]. There is a lack in the reach, due to which the gap of skill sets  between government officers is seen, but the CSOs are frequently organizing the national level sensitization events [4] and developing required resources via projects like Open Data Awareness Program [5], Nepal Data Literacy Program [6], etc.

indicators.justification:
Nepal doesn't collect and manage most of the political integrity datasets. The data relating to the political finance and asset declaration is collected according to the law, but it's not available to the general public. Furthermore, the data relating to lobbying register, public consultation, and RTI performance is not collected, as there are no such laws and policies which require doing so [1]. Also, the activities related to political integrity are scattered, as there are no such government agencies who manage it and publish the data. The Nepal National Governance Survey 2017/18 by Nepal Administrative Staff College highlight that having a robust integrity infrastructure and effective oversight institutions are absolutely critical for controlling the abuse of authority, corruption, or rent-seeking in Nepal [2].

[1] Phone interview with Tanka Aryal, Legal and Policy Expert and Krishna Sapkota, Programme Coordinator at Freedom Forum.
[2] Public Sector Integrity in Nepal: Transparency, Corruption and Accountability: http://fkb.nasc.org.np/assets/uploads/publication/file/1584337462_doc.pdf

indicators.justification:
Companies Act, 2063 (2006) requires the collection or publication of the beneficial ownership data on companies [1], and the Money Laundering Prevention Act, 2063 (2008) provides the legal provisions to prevent the laundering of criminally earned money [2]. The law has not explicitly mentioned the publication of information as structured data or open data. It only says that the "Memorandum of Association", which includes the tentative details of the beneficial ownership data, has to be published once the company is listed at the Office of Company Registrar [3]. The Open Ownership Country profile shows that Nepal is committed to the central and public register [4], but data in the OpenOwnership Register is not available.

indicators.justification:
Nepal currently doesn't have an explicit law or regulation that requires data collection and publication to be accessible to people with disabilities. However, section 17 "Right to Information" of Act Relating to Rights of Persons with Disabilities 2017 [1] guarantees the right to obtain information in the disabled-friendly and accessible formats. The Web Accessibility Guide [2] developed by the National Federation of the Disabled – Nepal has also defined various types of common barriers seen in the websites of Nepal. But, most of the data sites of Nepal are not that friendly as per the "Assessing The Effectiveness Of Data Sites In Nepal" report [3] of the world bank. The data-related laws like Nepal's statistics Act 2015 [4] and Right to Information Act 2007 [5] don't require publication to be accessible to people with disabilities.

[1] The Act Relating to Rights of Persons with Disabilities, 2074 (2017): https://www.lawcommission.gov.np/en/archives/category/documents/prevailing-law/statutes-acts/the-act-relating-to-rights-of-persons-with-disabilities-2074-2017
[2] The Web Accessibility Guide: https://nfdn.org.np/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Web-Accessibility-Guidebook-Accesssible-Version.pdf
[3] Assessing The Effectiveness Of Data Sites In Nepal: https://documents1.worldbank.org/curated/en/960741596604922376/pdf/Assessing-the-Effectiveness-of-Data-Sites-in-Nepal.pdf

indicators.justification:
Nepal currently doesn't have a comprehensive framework for consistent data management and publication. In the absence of the framework Statistics Act, 2015 [1] and the Right to Information Act, 2007 [2]  cover some aspects of consistent data publication but it's not comprehensive. Some of the major national-level census and surveys adopt the guideline of data management and publication included at the National Strategy for the Development of Statistical System [3], but it hasn't been properly established at all spheres of the government [4] due to the changing context.

indicators.justification:
Nepal currently doesn't have any kind of a comprehensive framework for data sharing. Statistics Act of Nepal [1] somewhat incorporates the details regarding how the Central Bureau of Statistics can handle the statistics related data and information, but it doesn't include the guidelines for all levels of government. No particular law defines how government should share data within government, with other sectors, within the private sectors, or more. Although the many assessments [2] [3] have highlighted the development of the data-sharing strategy to increase the availability and usability of government data. The complex legal and policy environment has been a long-term constraint to data sharing and use in Nepal [4].

indicators.justification:
The Privacy Act, 2075 (2018) [1] of Nepal overall covers the protection of personal data within the public bodies but it fails to bind the private sectors from misusing the data as private sectors are not incorporated [2]. Also, the current applicable laws do not prescribe provisions for notification in the situation of a data breach and the emerging issue of algorithmic decision-making [3]. Details regarding the consent, responsibilities for data holders, rights to correct, and rights of redress have been defined clearly.

indicators.justification:
Nepal currently doesn't have an explicit law or regulation for open data [1], due to which members of the open data community voiced frustration at the absence of an eco-system to support their efforts. In the absence of explicit law or regulation, Nepal's Right to Information Act 2007 [2] has been playing a vital role [3], which demands proactive information disclosure and reactive releases of specific information. Open Government Data Action Plan was submitted to the Prime Minister's Office where it is currently awaiting approval [4] and the Data for Development (D4D) Nepal program is also currently developing model "Open Data Policy for Federal Nepal" [5].

indicators.justification:
The Constitution of Nepal requires the collection and publication of data on public finances [1] by all tires of government; the national, provincial, and local governments of Nepal. It has a dedicated section defining State Legislative Procedures, State Financial Procedures, Local Financial Procedures, Auditor General, etc. Although, the publication of the data in the structured form is not mentioned in the law. The Right to Information Act 2007 [2] guarantees citizens access to public information, but for that, the citizen has to submit the request demanding the information. the stakeholder engagement strategy [3] document produced by the Office of Auditor General [4] has provided space for Citizen Participatory Audit and Financial Ordinance 2078 [5] published by the Ministry of Finance [6] guarantees the information to be updated. As per the country report of the Open Budget Survey 2019 [7], Nepal has improved budget transparency but the room for participation is still there [8].

indicators.justification:
In Nepal, all government officials, including the prime minister, ministers, members of the parliament, and civil servants, are required to declare their income and assets under the Commission for the Investigation of Abuse of Authority Act 1991 [1], and Prevention of Corruption Act 2002 [2]. The heads of state, ministers, and members of the parliament have to declare their properties (along with evidence) upon taking office and annually. Similarly, civil servants are obliged to declare their assets upon joining the civil service and on an annual basis [3]. According to the law, the Commission for the Investigation of Abuse of Authority [4] is responsible for ensuring that members of the government and civil servants submit their asset declarations. The National Vigilance Centre (NVC) [5] is, according to the Prevention of Corruption Act, responsible for monitoring the declarations. The data can be submitted online using the portal [6] or by filling the printed form and submitting it to the designated bodies as mentioned in the Nepal Gazette [7].

[1] Commission for the Investigation of Abuse of Authority Act, 2048 (1991): https://www.lawcommission.gov.np/en/wp-content/uploads/2018/10/commission-for-the-investigation-of-abuse-of-authority-act-2048-1991.pdf
[2] The Prevention of Corruption Act, 2059 (2002 A.D): https://www.lawcommission.gov.np/en/wp-content/uploads/2018/10/prevention-of-corruption-act-2059-2002.pdf
[3] Asset declaration regimes in selected Asian countries: https://www.u4.no/publications/asset-declaration-regimes-in-selected-asian-countries.pdf (page 3)

indicators.justification:
Nepal currently doesn't have any laws, regulations, policies, and guidance that provides a basis for collecting and publishing data on lobbying activities. Also, there are no dedicated lobbying registration agencies. The process of lobbying activities is scattered and informal, which vastly depends upon the civil societies projects. Usually, the civil societies organized meetings, workshops, and interaction programs with related stakeholders, parliamentary representatives, and others to discuss the policy or topics which they want to lobby. Based on the discussion, a memorandum of understanding or certain documents is developed, which then is submitted to the relevant government agencies for further consideration and discussion [1]. Therefore the collection of data on those types of lobbying activities entirely depends on the civil societies and the CIVICUS Civil Society Index report for Nepal has revealed that civil society in Nepal is overall not very strong [2].

[1] Phone interview with Tanka Aryal, Legal and Policy Expert and Krishna Sapkota, Programme Coordinator at Freedom Forum.
[2] CIVICUS Civil Society Index report for Nepal: http://www.civicus.org/media/CSI_Nepal_Country_Report.pdf

indicators.justification:
Nepal currently doesn't have any laws, regulations, policies, and guidance that provides a basis for collecting and publishing data generated through and about public consultation on rulemaking [1]. In fact, going for public consultation is not mandatory.  Some of the ministries or regulatory agencies share the proposals which intended to be adopted/implemented through the public notices, gazette, and government circulars as well as booklets and the website of the Ministry of Law and Justice [2]. Stakeholders Engagement Strategy (2019 - 2023) [3] of the Office of the Auditor General provides the basis for the public consultation for the budget and audits. But the collection and publication of data generated through and about public consultation are not mentioned in any laws.

indicators.justification:
Office of the Company Registrar Nepal has opened up some amount of company registration data as part of their Open Government Data (OGD) initiatives [1], but the data lacks a vast amount of other required information like the details of the accounts, directors, shareholders, license, etc. due to which the available data can't be used to support due diligence. indicators.justification:
As the political integrity data of Nepal is not well collected, managed, and published [1], there have been very limited cases of actors or entities using this kind of data for accountability purposes. The data are scatted and are difficult to access. But some of the civil societies and media houses are using the Right to Information Act 2064 (2007) [2], to request and access the data from the government. The media organization like the Centre for Investigative Journalism Nepal [3] are using the data and information to generate various kinds of investigative reports [4], whereas the CSOs like Nepal in Data and Transparency International Nepal [5] are using the scatted data to generated meaningful infographics [6], research and factsheet.
